Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Studying the Strong Nuclear Force at Augustana College
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award makes possible the creation of a new scientic program and laboratory at Augustana College in Sioux Falls, South Dakota, devoted to the study of the strong nuclear force, the force responsible for the binding of protons and neutrons in a nucleus. The central question that will be studied in this award is an understanding of the kinematics of low-energy gluons, the particles that mediate the strong force, in the nucleus. This will be studied with the construction of a new detector component to be added to the PHENIX experiment that will measure small angle production of
This program in strong nuclear physics will be the first of its kind in South Dakota. It provides those in the state and the region access to studying this physics where they have little opportunity. The award will fund research for undergraduates studying both physics and pre-engineering. The educational benefit for the students is broad. Both data analysis and detector development will be conducted, skills which are of general use to any physics or engineering field. Their research experience will teach or reinforce skills learned in computer science, mathematics, and in physics. For beginning undergraduates, research in this area will introduce them early to more advanced concepts giving them additional exposure aiding the learning process. Those interested in engineering will benefit from the detector testing and development that will be done on site. Further, since science is not done alone, students will travel to other institutions and to Brookhaven National Laboratory to help install and maintain the detector. This will provide them with opportunities to meet scientists from around the world and put them in contact with potential graduate schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided Augustana College (now Augustana University) and South Dakota a first-of-its kind laboratory to study the strong nuclear force, the force responsible for the binding of protons and neutrons in the nucleus and for energy generation in the sun. The PI continued as a member of good standing with the PHENIX experiment at Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, New York and Augustana became a founding member of the sPHENIX collaboration. These experiements study the strong nuclear force using collisions of heavy nuclei, such as gold, at very high energy. At these energies the quarks and gluons that make up the proton and neutron collide directly via the strong nuclear force.

The group focused on studying the low-energy gluon content of the nucleus. Because of the binding of protons and neutrons in the nucleus, naive expection was that there should be more gluons per proton in the nucleus than a bare proton. World data indicate this might not be the clase, although with large uncertainties. The PI completed analysis and was the lead writer on a PHENIX paper published as an Editor's Selection in Physical Review C. The paper measured electron-muon pairs that decay from particles called charm quarks. These charm quarks are produced by gluon collisions and therefore directly probe the gluon content of the nucleus. The paper showed that there are fewer electron-muon pairs in deuterium-gold collisions per proton-proton collision than in proton-proton collisions. The fewer pairs is consistent with the idea that there are fewer low-energy gluons in the nucleus per proton than in a bare proton.

To study this topic further the PHENIX experiment proposed building the MPC-EX detector and extension to an existing electromagnetic calorimeter. The MPC-EX is a silicon-tungsten preshower detector and is highly segmented designed to measure photons produced directly from the collisions of gluons. The PI and several undergraduate students participated in the testing of the detector prior to installation and in the initial and on-going analysis from the 2016 data when the detector was installed.

The PHENIX experiment ceased data taking in 2016 and the sPHENIX experiment was created to design a new, second-generation detector to continue in PHENIX's place. The sPHENIX experiment has an extensive electromagnetic and hadronic calorimeter system to measure as many particles from the collision as possible. These calorimeters will produce light that will be collected by approximately 100,000 silicon photomultipliers (SiPMs). Augustana is planning on helping test a fraction of those SiPMs. This grant has supported the effort to create a testing station and design of those tests.

During the lifetime of the grant, 11 different undergraduate students were supported with summer research experience. Five of those students were supported for 2-3 summers. Two of those students presented at Conference Experience for Undergraduates at the American Physical Society Division of Nuclear Physics meeting. One of those students presented three separate times. Students have learned a variety of skills that have informed their vocation. Software projects required a variety of languages including C++, python, and SQL databasing. Hardware projects were available such as mechanical design of dark boxes and circuit design for test benches. Students that have graduated from the group are currently employed in a variety of STEM fields including engineering, information technology, and defense contracting.
